_prev_prog_3.PHA_OtherTechnique: Brainstorm potential problems and history with subject matter experts who have used the equipment for numerous years
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Environmental Health personnel at boundary of operation with analyzers
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Installation of new Tanker Storage Bays with mitigation system.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Deluge modifications, containment coating and Tank Vault modification to stage MMH tankers.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary
	1. Description of Stationary Source
	John F. Kennedy Space Center (KSC) is the major NASA installation for launch operations and related programs in support of manned space missions.  The KSC core business is to provide space system processes, test, and launch techniques and to develop associated technologies.  The day-to-day operation of KSC is managed by NASA KSC personnel with support provided by contractors.
	KSC spans approximately 220 square miles on the east central coast of Florida.  Only a very small part of the total acreage of KSC has been developed or designated for NASA operational and industrial use.  Because Merritt Island was found to include prime habitat for unique and endangered wildlife, NASA entered into an agreement with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) to establish a wildlife preserve, known as the Merritt Island National Wildlife Refuge (MINWR), within the boundaries of KSC.  In addition, an agreement with the Department of Interior (USDI) caused most of the Canaveral National Seashore (CNS) to fall within KSC when the CNS was created by Public Law 93-626.
	2. NASA Prevention Programs
	Two of KSC¿s four guiding principles are ¿Safety and Health First¿ and ¿Environmental Leadership¿.  KSC is in compliance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119.  The PSM program has been developed throughout KSC to minimize the potential for fires, explosions, and accidental releases of highly hazardous, toxic, flammable, reactive, or explosive chemicals and receives full support of management and involvement of employees at all levels.  The PSM program prevents chemical accidents from occurring and ensures that facility operations remain safe to work team members and the general public.  The program achieves this goal by taking a comprehensive approach, which involves integrating technologies, procedures, and management practices.  The program is based on the principle that facilities will remain s

oint to ensure that the State is notified of any disaster at KSC.  The KSC Emergency Operations Center and the Brevard County Emergency Operations Center jointly monitor the same emergency radio frequencies and are in sync and responsive to joint alert notifications during an emergency.  

4. Regulated Substances Handled
KSC stores Monomethyl Hydrazine (MMH) over the threshold amount.  MMH is used as a propellant in the Orbital Maneuvering System/Reaction Control System (OMS/RCS).  It is delivered to KSC by tankers and stored and processed at the Fuel Storage Area No. 1 (FSA-1) at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station (CCAFS).  The tankers hold a maximum capacity of 2,500 gallons (18,335 lbs).  FSA-1 has modified the tanker staging facility to receive and stage regulated quantities of MMH above the threshold value of 2,066 gallons within a containment of 1,083-square feet that drains into a covered sump.  Two storage tank bays of the Facility 77800 were modified to accept the parking of 2500-gallon DOT MC-338 (exempted tankers) that has an access ramp to provide controlled drainage into the facility sump.  MMH processing of 2,500 gallon (18,335 lbs) tankers at FSA-1 is performed at facility 77800, processing area, and remains a covered process of the RMP rule.  These tankers are typically in route to another facility at CCAFS or KSC and require weigh-in or processing at FSA-1 prior to delivery.  Processing of a tanker is not considered storage.
At Launch Complex A and B, MMH is stored at the Hypergol fuel facility and the maximum intended inventory is 55,845 lbs. MMH is delivered to the launch pads in 2,500 gallon tankers (18,335 lbs) which are off-loaded to the larger storage tank at each pad. 
Description of Worst-case and Alternative Release Scenarios
FSA-1 Monomethyl Hydrazine Process:
The worst-case release scenario is rupture of a 2,500-gallon tanker during storage, releasing 18,335 lbs of monomethyl hydrazine.  The total quantity spilled is mitigated to a 1,083 sq

uare-foot area, which is drained to a covered sump.  Under worst-case weather conditions, taking into consideration the passive mitigation and using the EPA¿s RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance (published May 24, 1996), the monomethyl hydrazine fumes could travel 2.2 miles before dispersing enough to no longer pose a hazard to the public or the environment.  At this distance the radius of impact remains inside the Cape Canaveral Air Force Station (CCAFS) property, and public receptors that will be affected include:  the Banana River and the Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Visitor¿s Center.  No residential areas are located in the area of concern.
The MMH tankers are a MC-338 type jacketed pressure vessel.  Although there may be several tankers onsite, stored near each other, each tanker is designed to be an independent facility.  They are designed to DOT classification DOT-E-10631, for the transportation of hypergolic Fuels.  They have an inner and outer vessel made of SA 240 Grade 304L stainless steel.  The tankers are designed with a relief system and can withstand front and side impacts of 55 miles per hour and a fall of 50 feet without any puncture of the inner vessel.  The tankers are also designed to withstand immersion into a fire of 681 to 1000 degrees Fahrenheit without danger of a BLEVE, or Boiling Liquid Expansion Vapor Explosion.  The worst-case scenario, therefore, is highly unlikely.
The alternative release scenario for the MMH tanker was derived from experience, estimations and input from various groups including Safety.  Due to active and passive controls in place, the credible spill can be limited to 8 ounces.  Engineering controls are used to minimize any release.  Generally, the processes are considered ¿closed systems¿, i.e. connections are made with valves closed and there is no free flow of liquid through the atmosphere.  The hypergol activities are conducted in a contained slip, which also has a sump.  If there was a release, it could

be washed down with water and contained in the sump.  In the event of a hose leak, the operation can be shut down almost immediately, and in the event a valve were to fail and could not be closed, the tankers have an emergency ¿can¿ that can be used to cap the leak.
Using EPA¿s RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance (published May 24, 1996), the alternative release scenario of an 8-ounce spill could potentially travel 317 feet before dispersing enough to no longer pose a hazard to the public or the environment.  At this distance the general public would not be affected.
LC39A/B Monomethyl Hydrazine Process:
The worst-case release scenarios for the monomethyl hydrazine processes at LC39 A and B are the rupture of the pad fuel storage tank and the 2,500-gallon tanker.  The storage tank volume is 10,000 gallons and the maximum capacity load is 7,650 gallons (55,845 lbs).  An instantaneous release under worst-case weather conditions, taking into consideration the spill surface area of 735 ft2 due to the sumped area, and using the EPA¿s RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance, the monomethyl hydrazine fumes could travel 2.2 miles before dispersing enough to no longer pose a hazard to the public or the environment.  At this distance, public receptors that will be affected include:  parts of Playalinda Beach, the Atlantic Ocean, the Banana River and NASA/KSC tour bus stops.  No residential areas are located in the area of concern.
The 2,500-gallon MMH tanker¿s worst-case scenario is an unmitigated release of 18,335 lbs instantaneously forming a 1-centimeter deep pool.  Using the EPA¿s RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance, the monomethyl hydrazine fumes could travel 7.4 miles before dispersing enough to no longer pose a hazard to the public or the environment.  At this distance, public receptors that will be affected include:  parts of Playalinda Beach, the Atlantic Ocean, the Indian and Banana Rivers and NASA/KSC tour bus stops.  No residential areas are located

in the area of concern.
The alternative release scenario for the MMH storage tank process was derived from discussions with system and safety engineering, as well as the process hazard analysis.  The scenario modeled is a failure of the MMH supply line at the crossover spool interface.  The commodity in the line between the crossover spools and the 207 ft level of the Fixed Service Structure is lost, approximately 250 gallons.  There is no passive mitigation for this release.  Using EPA¿s RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance the alternative release scenario of a 250-gallon spill could potentially travel 0.43 miles before dispersing enough to no longer pose a hazard to the public or the environment.  At this distance no public receptors are affected.
The alternative release scenario for the MMH 2,500 gallon tankers was derived from experience, estimations and input from various groups including Safety.  Due to active and passive controls in place, the credible spill can be limited to 8 ounces.  Engineering controls are used to minimize any release.  Generally, the processes are considered ¿closed systems¿, i.e. connections are made with spools closed and there is no free flow of liquid through the atmosphere.  In the event of a hose leak, the operation can be shut down almost immediately, and in the event a spool were to fail and could not be closed, the tankers have an emergency ¿can¿ that can be used to cap the leak.
Using EPA¿s RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance (published May 24, 1996), the alternative release scenario of an 8-ounce spill could potentially travel 317 feet before dispersing enough to no longer pose a hazard to the public or the environment for the MMH processes.  At this distance the general public would not be affected.

6. 	Accident History
The accidental release history of all covered processes was reviewed to determine whether, for the past five years, an accidental release resulted in off-site death, injury, or response or restora

tion activities for an exposure of an environmental receptor.
None of the covered processes at KSC have experienced such a release, or any release that has affected off-site receptors.
7. 	Planned changes to improve safety
KSC is in the process of making a major cultural change on how safety is implemented at this center. Historically, we have relied on a large safety organization to provide hands-on safety support to major hazardous operations. This has served the center well but reviews with outside industry indicate that additional improvements can only be made by empowering the line organizations with the responsibility to conduct their operations safely. This cultural change is being implemented through classroom training such as the DuPont STOP Program, Policy Statements released by the Center Director, and with progress monitored by a Cultural Shift Steering Committee composed of the first line Directors. 
Within the past year the Safety and Mission Assurance Directorate established a KSC Human Factors Office chartered with establishing a center wide Integrated Process Team to embed human factors concepts and methodologies into all organizations. This is being accomplished through training, providing root cause analysis and lessons learned for close calls and incidents as well as incorporation of human factor elements into the IRIS mishap reporting system.
The KSC Safety and Mission Assurance Directorate is in the process of implementing a major reorganization that will consolidate functions therefore allowing for increased efficiencies with the existing manpower resources.
